projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: ENGLANDS REIOYCING AT THE PRELATS downfall.
OR, GODS GOODNESSE and mercy to England in delivering them from the cruell tyranny of blood-thirsty Prelats.

p.hi: Many are the troubles of the Righteous, but the Lord delivereth them out of all.
Comfort us according to the dayes that thou hast afflicted us, and according to the years we have seen evill.

div.p: ENGLAND, Printed in the yeare of the down-fall of the Prelats. 1641.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: CHristian Reader, thou hast here presented unto thee in this small Treatise, the cruell Tyranny of the wicked Bishops, and Gods goodnesse and great mercy in easing the Land of them, in turning their plots to their own Destruction, and in making them a derision to all the world: Therfore let us all blesse and praise God for all his mercies to us, and long and desire the downfall of Rome, and al his brood, with all the enemies of the Church, that so our Church may be a glorious Church, even to the coming of our Lord Iesus Christ, even so be it, Amen.

div.head: ENGLANDS REIOYCING at the Prelats downfall, Or, Gods goodnesse and mercy to ENGLAND in delivering them from the cruell Tyranny of blood-thirsty Prelats.

epigraph.q: PSAL. 123. 3. Have mercy upon us ô Lord, have mercy upon us, for we have suffered too much contempt.
PSAL. 120. 6. My soule hath too long dwelt with him that hateth peace.
PSAL. 119. 126. It is time for thee to worke ô Lord, for they have destroyed thy Law.

div.p:
THere ever hath bin, and is now, and still there ever will be (so long as the Gods people will have enemies, as long as they continue here. world stands) enemies against the Church and People of God, bloody enemies, cruell Tyrants: but still the Lord ever hath bin, and is now, and will be the
deliverer of his People; the Lord doth confound their enemies and trap them in their own snares; they lay baits privily to intrap the Righteous, The wicked lay snares for the Righteous, and are snared themselves. and are snared in their own snares; the Lord who sits in heaven, and eyes and beholds the wayes and plots of the wicked: he wisely orders and contrives their own plots to their own Destruction, as witnesse that hellish Powder Treason of blood-thirsty Papists are cruell Tyrants to Gods people and Church. Prelats, who sought to have blowed up the whole Assembly of Parliament; and when they thought themselves most sure, then God discovered it, and turned it to their own Ruine.

And also in Queen Maryes dayes, how cruell In Q. Maryes time were bloody dayes with the Papists. were they to all Christians, insomuch that whosoever would not turn to them to worship Baal, there was no mercy with them, but to fire and No mercy to be had of Papists. faggot they must goe, bloody-minded men they were. But yet the Lord in the end did overthrow God will overthrow their plots. them and consumed them; they must not alwayes Tyrannize over Gods people: For though God let them alone for a time, yet in the end he will laugh at their destruction: The rod of the wicked shall not alway lye on the backe of the righteous, God will ease them, and deliver them.

And now also God is very good to his people, farre beyond all hopes or expectation: for our God will not forsake his people. Lordly Prelats have so Lorded it over all Gods people, as scarce any have bin free from trouble, but that the Bishops, our Lordly Prelats have persecuted them by Pursevanting knaves, some way Pursevants are knaves by Bonnirags confession. or other: and their impudencie was grown to such a height, that Ministers dare hardly Preach; and if they did, they were tyed to a just houre:
and Pursevants were redy to insnare them if they That was because they would have brought in Popery under the name of Religion. spoke any thing against Popery: Nor people could not assemble themselves together in any duty in private, much lesse publick, but they were had before his Grace, and were mockt and scoft at by the name of Puritans, and many other absurd names, so that they had the world at their beck and command, that all the world groaned Bishops were never more hated then now. under them, they were (I meane our Lordly Prelats) a burden both to Church and State.

How had they corrupted Gods worship, abused his Ordinances, despised his Ministers, rejected The Lord hath bin very much wronged. his Word, dishonoured his Name, prophaned his Sabbaths, persecuted his people, and robbing God of his Honour. O Brethren, these are grievous things: and when a Land is guilty of these things, and justly might the Lord have done it. the Lord must needs avenge himselfe, as faith the Lord, Shall not I visit for these things?

Consider in the first place, how they have corrupted Gods worship, in turning their Table Altarwise, and rayling of it, and making the people come up to it, and kneel round about it; in reading their Second Service there; and in consecrating They all are for the outside worship, and never look after the heart within. the Table or Chancell, as though the Table or Chancell had bin more holyer then any part of the Church else; and also in wearing the white Surplice, Lawn Sleeves, Tippet, foure corner Cap, &c. as though God required these outside Ceremonies, when as indeed this is a corrupting of Gods worship, and so bowing at the Name of Jesus, as if that were above Jehovah

Secondly, consider how they have abused thine ordinances, in setting up of Idolatry and Superstition,
and labouring to pull down thine Ordinances by their good will: they would not have All things were hatefull to him, but Idolatry. us have a Lecture once a week, nay not on the Lords day: for they set out a Book for Liberty on the Sabbath, in spending the afternoons in Sports and Past-times, and so putting down all Sermons in the afternoones, as one of the Prelats most notoriously But this was the way to their own destruction, as now you see. boasted and said, I thank God I have but one Lecture in all my Diocesse: ô most wicked Blasphemour, to thank God that he hath done wickedly: ô this is a high contempt of Gods Ordinances, and abusing them, when men strive with all their might and maine to subvert the Ordinances of God, as our proud Prelats did.

Thirdly, consider how they have contemned and despised the Ministers of God, as that they would not suffer them to teach: for if they did, they must cringe, and bow, and be very Ceremoniall; or else if they will not, they are clapt up in Prison. And of late that sinfull Synod made an Oath, that all Ministers must take, and so they thought to insnare all good Ministers, for none would take it that feared God, and then by thi •
Oath, they would have silenc'd all good men, suchs a plot it was, that one would have thought all the Devils in hell could not have thought: but now it is cleane contrary to their expectation.

Fourthly, consider how they rejected his Word in adding and diminishing what they pleased, and in being carelesse and negligent of his Word in rejecting Gods Word and Religion, & setting up of a Religion of their own, and in making a set forme of Prayer, as they pleased, for Ministers to
say before their Sermons, as if so be none were so holy as they (as they thought themselvs) when indeed none were so wicked as they: ô this rejecting of Gods Word would have caused him to have taken it away: For where a People once rejects his Word, then he departs from them.

Fiftly consider, they have dishonoured his Name, by swearing by his Name, as Lord, or God, as many of our Prelats doe, who (at least should know better) doe, yea many of our Ceremoniall Ministers, that will come out of a Tavern or Alehouse, and goe up in the Pulpit to preach, and call upon the name of God, whenas this is a dishonouring Gods name, and a mocking him to his face, when they say and promise one thing, and doe clean contrary. God commands us to honour him, and we dishonour him, to honour the creatures, wicked men.

Sixtly, Consider how they have prophaned his Sabbaths, in giving men liberty on the Sabbath: wheras God hath set it apart to be kept holy to himselfe, they gave liberty to men to prophane the Sabbath, to make it a day of mirth and Pastimes: ô this is most abominable, they contradict God, and break the Fourth Commandement, wherein God has commanded men to keep the Sabbath day holy: and how is it kept when they keep it unholy, and prophane it?
Seventhly, Consider how most barbarously they persecuted Gods people, in dismembring and disfiguring, and whipping, and Pilloring, and Fettering, and Imprisoning, and Banishing, and Silencing, &c.

As first, in cutting off those Three Worthy Three Worthy Champions of Christ suffered all patiently. mens Eares, Mr. Burton, Dr. Bastwicke, and Mr. Pryn: and then Fining them, and Banishing them to Perpetuall Imprisonment, which was against both the Laws of God and men: for they were not found guilty of any thing: ô it was most cruell dealing, not like Christians, but as dogs. And also good Dr. Layton, that hath bin both branded and whipt, and his nose slit, and Imprisoned. And This was the Christian mans tryall. Mr. John Lilburne, that hath bin whipt and gagged, and Fettered, and Pillorified, and Imprisoned. And so many other of Gods Children did the Lordly Prelats persecute, and Tyrannize over. How did they Lord it over all men in their bitter High Commission, worse then the Spanish All will turn to their owne ruine. Inquisition: but Pride now hath had a fall, they now are fallen into the Pit that they digged for others.

Seventhly, they robbed God of his glory, and Robbing God of his glory, giving all to the creatures that God should have. honour, they forsook the living God, and set up Images, and Idols, and they worshiped them: this was in some places, and they would have had it in all places, had not they bin crost of their designes; for how many scores of Ministers had they Silenced, and set up dumb dogs in their Rome, that so they might (when all good Ministers were put out) rule as Lords and Kings; and every one should have honoured them: for in their Courts they sate like Gods, and not like Men, making every one subject to them; and thus they robbed God of his honour: ô these were heavy things, and certainly God will be avenged of these Prelats: and indeed now he hath begun, in that he hath turned all to their own ruine and destruction. God in
pitty and mercy towards his people, called a Parliament, which England longed for, contrary to our wicked Bishops mind: for they little thought of a Parliament, for if they had, they would never have Tyrannized so as they did; they thought they might doe what they would, for no body durst say, why doe you so? The truth was, they neither feared God nor man, for if they had, they would have thought then that God would have called them to an account for all, and then they would not have done so: but they were departed from the living Lord, and did according to their own hearts lust, as in Ie▪ 9. 13. 14. They have forsaken my law which I set before them, and have not obeyed my voyce, neither walke thereafter. But they have walked after the stubbornes of their own hearts. Yea they have walked very stubbornly before God, doing all things contrary to Gods will, as in Le. 26. 1. 40. They have walked contrary unto me: and therfore saith God in the next verse 41. Because they have walked contrary unto me, therefore will I walke contrary unto them. God will serve them in their own kind: for they that forsake him, he will forsake them, and Miserable are al they whom the Lord departs from. leave them to their own destruction: as you see he hath done these Lordly Prelats: they forsook God, and God forsook them, and hath brought They are descended from their Palace to their Prison. them to their own destruction: that wheras before they sate as Lords and Kings in their Pallace, now they sit as Prisoners in their Prison, yet they never thought of this, nor if any had told them of it, would not have beleeved it: for they thought it was impossible, they had so seated themselves. And I dare be bold to say, that had not the Lord crossed their wicked designes by
this time Canterbury would have bin entring into his Popeship: for as a worthy Knight sayes, He But the little great man was deceived. pleads for a Popeship under the name of a Patriarch, and it was too true, as was apparent by his actions, and by what he intended to doe; as to have silenced all Godly Ministers with that damnable Oath hatcht in Hell; and then we should have had fire and fagot. But ô blessed, and for ever blessed and praised be the Lord our God, that hath eased the Land of this great burden: for they are of late hated of all men, both Scotch men, and English men: for they by sending over the Scotch Service Book, and imposing it on them, was the cause of all this: they could not be content to rule and Lord it here, but they must there also too, & so made a rod for their own back: for they by that meanes brought the Scots hither, and so they bred hatred between the two united Kingdomes, and would have made them pierc'd their swords in one anothers side. But the wise God hath now brought them into shame and confusion, that now our Lordly Prelats hang down their heads, for this happy Parliament hath quell'd all the Canterburian Faction, that now they have nothing to say: and now I beleeve they wish they had never bin Bishops at all, but some handicraft Trade, which indeed there are too too many more, are more fitter for the Plough then the Pulpit, Idoll Ministers, that are negligent in Gods worship, and in preaching his Word; when as God saith, Cursed are they that doe the worke of the Lord negligently, Jer. 48. 10. And how negligent are our Lordly Bishops, that do not preach once in a whole year,
when as Bishops should be preaching Bishops, and not Lording Bishops: for in Zacha. 11. 17. Woe unto ye Idol shepheards that leave your flock, the sword shalbe upon you, &c. And yet how many Idoll shepheards have we now that famish their flock, and are idle and lazie? and how many Idoll worshipers such as worship Idols, when God forbids it, as in Levit. 19. 4. Ye shall not turne unto Idolls, nor make your molten Gods, for I am the Lord your God: yet they made them graven Images, and worshipped them, for all that the Lord forbids them, and they walked every way stubbornly against God: and therfore sayes God in Pro. 1. 24, 25, 26. Because I have called, and ye refused, and I stretched forth my hand, and none would regard, but have despised my counsell, I will laugh at your destruction, and mocke when your feare cometh. And also in Jer. 9. 13. Because they have forsaken my Law which I set before them, and have not obeyed my voyce, I will send a sword after them till I have consumed them: So that God leaves those that leave him, yea those that walke not in the way of God shall not prosper, as you see these wicked Prelats that did all according to their own wills, and so run headlong to destruction, for those things which Nothing that they take in hand against the godly shall prosper. Zach. 9. 9. they sought the ruine of others with, have turned to their own ruine; and England hath great cause to rejoyce at their downfalls, for they were enemies to God and his people; as in Lament. 3. 59, 60. Lamen. 3. 59, 60 Lord thou hast seen our wrongs, the fore judge thou our cause. Thou hast seen all their vengeance, and all their devises against us; and 64. Therfore give them The Lord will recompence them. a recompence according to the works of their hands Now the Lord hath refresht his people wonderfully,
in relieving of them: for now the Lord hath brought home those 3 Worthies, that were Banished God can do all things. so farre, contrary to all our expectations, for few thought to have seen them all here alive againe: but all things are possible unto God. And so in setting at liberty other Captives, as silenced Ministers, and others. O this is a great mercy, that God out of his free mercy and love to his people should give them such a gracious deliverance from the cruell Tyranny of these Prelates, who ruled and raigned as Lords over them: for the wicked must not thinke alwayes to Tyrannize over them, and thinke the Lord will not avenge himselfe of them, no, no, for the Lord hath promised to his people the utter ruine of their enemies at last: yea, the Lord hath said, All things shall worke together for the best of them that love him. And therfore, though they be persecuted, it is not alwayes, it is but for a time. Now God will stand up to plead their own cause, that wheras Gods cause shall be pleaded. before his people were called in question, and Imprisoned; now they who called them in question; are called in question themselves, and have the same punishment inflicted on them, as they They are paid with their own coine. would have inflicted on others: for our Lordly Bishops, and other inferiour Doctors, that silenced other good men, are now silenc'd themselves, and that according to justice: for there is no Court like unto the Parliament for justice and No Court like unto the Parliament. equity; now all things are called in question that were wrong, to be set right. But in my Lords Court at Lambeth, there was nothing but injustice. Pursevanting knaves would come and domineere No justi •• at al. and carry any one, who they would,
before his Grace, and make them spend their money, and their time; and in the end know not why, nor for what; they were brought in, and And yet there was no remedy▪ there was no helpe at all for it. But here the Parliament is a Court of justice, doing no man wrong, but righting the wronged, and easing the oppressed. And I hope the Parliament will take it into consideration, that there may be no Bishops, for the Church may be governed without No Bishops. No Bishops. Bishops: or at least, if there be, to curbe them of their power, that if they doe ordaine Bishops, that they may be preaching Bishops, and not Bishops that will preach, it may be wilbe accepted of. Lording Bishops, not have so much power and Authority as they had, and not so many benefices, when many good men are without: but I leave all to that grave and honourable Assemblies disposing, beseeching God to protect, and keep them, and continue them together.

But to conclude, here you see Gods goodnesse For Conclusion. to his people, in curbing the Prelats: and here let all take notice and observe (all that are the enemies It is in vaine to work mischief against the Church of God. of the people of God) that it is in vaine to plot or contrive any mischief against the godly, seeing that God turnes all to their own ruine, seeing that God is their God, and they his people, yea they are his Iewels, and therfore he will have a care of Gods people are his delight: therfore he will have a care of them. them, that none doe hurt them: why then this is for great terror to the wicked, that though they sit up early and late, night and day to invent mischiefe and wickednesse against the people of God, yet it is in vain, for all is turned to their ruine: why then Bretheren in Christ, rejoyce all ye godly, shout for joy, thy
Zach. 9. 9. King cometh unto thee. O here is matter of great
joy, Christ is come to bring deliverance, all the enemies of the Church, and his Gospell is falling, the Prelats downfall is hastening; and then the It is begun already. Gospell of Jesus Christ will flourish more then ever before, and shine more clearer: for so long as the enemies of it raigned, it could never shine forth in its cleare light: therfore let it be alwayes all our Prayers to God, that he would accomplish the downfall of Babylon, to ruine that man of Sin. And Lord confound all the enemies of thy Church and people: let them be confounded and put to shame that seek after my soule: let them be turned back, and brought to confusion that imagine mine hurt. Psal. 35. 4.

closer.signed: Written by an ill willer to the Romish brood.
